#Text=Abdul Aziz Hotak
#Text=Shāh Abdul Azīz Hotak
#Text=( Pashto : عبد العزیز هوتک‎ ; died 1717 ) was the second ruler of the Ghilji Hotak dynasty of Kandahar , in what is now the modern state of Afghanistan .
#Text=He was crowned in 1715 after the death of his brother , Mirwais Hotak .
#Text=He is the father of Ashraf Hotak , the fourth ruler of the Hotak dynasty .
#Text=Abdul Aziz was killed in 1717 by his nephew Mahmud Hotak .
#Text=Early life
#Text=Abdul Aziz was born in a well known , rich and political family in the Kandahar area .
#Text=His family was involved in social and community services since long ago .

#Text=He was the son of Salim Khan and Nazo Tokhi ( also known as " Nazo Anaa " ) , grandson of Karum Khan and great grandson of Ismail Khan , a descendant of Malikyar , the ancient head of Hottaki or Hotaks .
#Text=The Hottaki is a strong branch of Ghilji , one of the main tribes among the Pashtun people .
#Text=Hajji Amanullah Hottak reports in his book that the Ghilji tribe is the original residents of Ghor or Gherj .
#Text=This tribe migrated later to obtain lands in southeastern Afghanistan and multiplied in these areas . [ 1 ]
#Text=Greater Kandahar ( Candahar ) during the Safavid dynasty and Mughal period .
#Text=In 1707 , Kandahar was in a state of chaos due to it being fought for control by the Shi'a Persian Safavids and the Sunni Moghuls of India .

#Text=Mirwais Khan , a Sunni tribal chief whose influence with his fellow-countrymen made him an object of suspicion , was held as a political prisoner by the Safavid governor over the region , Gurgin Khan , and sent to the Safavids court at Isfahan .
#Text=He was later released and even allowed to meet with the Shah , Sultan Husayn , on a regular bases .

#Text=Having sown this seed of false trust and having completely ingratiated himself with the Persian Court , Mirwais sought and obtained permission to perform the pilgrimage to Mecca in Ottoman empire .
#Text=He had studied carefully all the military weaknesses of the by then heavily declined Safavids while he spent time there in their court . [ 2 ] [ 3 ]

#Text=It was in 1709 when Mirwais and Abdul Aziz began organizing his countrymen for a major uprising , and when a large part of the Persian garrison was on an expedition outside the city , followers of Mirwais and Abdul Aziz fell on the remainder and killed the greater number of them , including Gurgin Khan . [ 3 ]
#Text=The Pashtun tribes rankled under the ruling Safavids because of their continued attempts to forcefully convert them from Sunni to Shia Islam . [ 2 ]
#Text=After Gurgin Khan and his escort were killed during a picnic in April 1709 , the Hotak tribe took control of the city and the province . [ 4 ]
#Text=The Pashtun rebels then defeated a large Qizilbash and Persian army , sent to gain control over the area .

#Text=Several half-hearted attempts to subdue the rebellious city having failed , the Persian Government despatched Khusraw Khán , nephew of the late Gurgín Khán , with an army of 30,000 men to effect its subjugation , but in spite of an initial success , which led the Afgháns to offer to surrender on terms , his uncompromising attitude impelled them to make a fresh desperate effort , resulting in the complete defeat of the Persian army ( of whom only some 700 escaped ) and the death of their general .
#Text=Two years later , in .
#Text=1713 , another Persian army commanded by Rustam Khán was also defeated by the rebels , who thus secured possession of the whole province of Qandahár .
#Text=[ 3 ]
#Text=— Edward G. Browne , 1924
#Text=Death
#Text=Abdul Aziz wanted to make a peace treaty with the Persians but his country men were opposed to this idea so they forced Mahmud Hotak to murder him in 1717 .
#Text=In the same year he got succeeded by Mahmud Hotak .
#Text=Abdul Aziz is buried at a mausoleum next to his brother in the Kokaran section of Kandahar City in Afghanistan . [ 5 ]
